title: 103_s493
content: The "Hospital Cooperative Agreement Act" aims to promote collaboration among hospitals to reduce costs and enhance efficiency in healthcare delivery by avoiding unnecessary duplication of expensive medical services and equipment. Additionally, it introduces a Hospital Technology and Services Sharing Demonstration Program under the Public Health Service Act to facilitate this cooperation. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program awarding grants to hospitals for collaboration on expensive medical technology. The program aims to reduce costs, increase access to care, and improve quality of care. Eligible applicants must be hospitals submitting an application to the Secretary. To be eligible for a grant, a hospital must submit an application to the Secretary, expressing a desire to collaborate with other hospitals in the state or region for sharing medical technology or services. The application should include details about the activities planned under the cooperative agreement and any benefits that may be received by other participating hospitals. The Secretary requires hospitals to submit applications for grants to collaborate on sharing medical technology or services. The applications must include details of the planned activities, benefits for other participating hospitals, and any additional information deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research will develop evaluation guidelines for these applications, and the Secretary will evaluate them in consultation with the Agency. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, will evaluate applications for grants based on guidelines developed for enhancing hospital care quality and preserving hospital facilities in communities. The Secretary evaluates grant applications based on guidelines for enhancing hospital care quality, preserving hospital facilities, improving cost-effectiveness, resource utilization, and avoiding duplication. Grant amounts are to be used solely for facilitating these purposes. The grant amounts awarded under this section are to be used for facilitating collaboration among hospitals, not for purchasing facilities or capital equipment. Permissible uses include expenses for specialized personnel, administrative services, support services, and instructional programs. At least three grants must demonstrate cooperative agreements in rural areas. The grants awarded under this section are to be used for collaboration among hospitals, not for purchasing facilities or capital equipment. Permissible uses include specialized personnel, administrative services, support services, and instructional programs. At least three grants must demonstrate cooperative agreements in rural areas for increasing access to or quality of care. Cooperative agreements facilitated under this section shall involve sharing medical or high technology equipment or services among the hospitals involved. Cooperative agreements under this section involve sharing medical or high technology equipment or services among hospitals. Medical technology includes drugs, devices, and procedures used in medical care. Eligible services for sharing must have high capital or operating costs. The demonstration program established under this section allows for sharing high-cost medical services among hospitals for a term of 5 years, including mobile clinic services. The demonstration program allows for sharing high-cost medical services among hospitals for a term of 5 years, including mobile clinic services. After 5 years, a report will be submitted to Congress on the potential benefits of cooperative agreements in reducing healthcare costs, increasing access to medical services, and improving healthcare quality. Recommendations for future programs will also be included in the report. The report on the demonstration program will include recommendations from the Secretary for future cooperative agreements to reduce healthcare costs, increase access to medical services, and improve healthcare quality. Additionally, it clarifies that hospitals can enter into cooperative agreements without violating antitrust laws. The term 'antitrust laws' in this subsection refers to the Sherman Act, Federal Trade Commission Act, and Clayton Act. The Clayton Act, along with other antitrust laws, prohibits certain activities. Appropriations are authorized for enforcement of these laws from 1994 to 1998.
